Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task sits on the critical path for an external delivery promised to a client.
Expectation2: Enforcing the law and maintaining public order
Situation2: A public protest begins to escalate, with tension rising between opposing groups
Story:
I sat at my desk, eyes flicking between the urgent email from my manager and the live news feed on my phone. As a colleague, I was expected to finish the project report by tonight—my part was the last piece before we could deliver to the client, and everyone was counting on me. The pressure was suffocating; I knew any delay would ripple through the team and damage our reputation.

But then my phone buzzed again, this time with an alert from the precinct. A protest downtown was spiraling out of control, and all off-duty officers were being called in. As a police officer, I was sworn to uphold the law and keep the peace, especially when things got dangerous. My badge wasn’t just a job—it was a promise.

I stared at the screen, heart pounding. My team needed me to finish the report. The city needed me to help restore order. Both roles demanded my full attention, and I could feel the weight of their expectations crushing me from both sides. I took a shaky breath, torn between duty to my colleagues and my oath as an officer, knowing I had to choose, but not yet ready to decide.
